title: All Is Silence: A Deserted Lands Novel
features: As the world crumbles... Lizzie had it worse than most.Will she give up?A bat virus brought the world to its knees.At 17, Lizzie has scars on her arm and her heart, now she's alone.Surviving an apocalypse could push anyone to do the unthinkable.Her shotgun's loaded.She meets survivor, Spike, a hungry, silent man with a dog collar and gives him food.Things go to hell. People die. Some by her hands.When Lizzie is attacked, her box of family keepsakes is smashed.A phone number and a name peeks out from under the wrapping.Like a beacon. A stranger she thought was dead.Could he still be alive?She has to find out.Ride shotgun in this coming-of-age, post-apocaloptimistic road-trip.Because when you need it most, a single piece of hope can be all it takes.Get it now.
description: "Hardly the familiar post-apocalyptic novel of zombie attacks and desperate efforts to rebuild civilization--[

is] a personal story of a scared girl and the survivors she finds in the ruins of her world. Lizzie is hard-edged and gritty, vulnerable and kind. Her personality is so compelling that she grabs you by the heart and pulls you along until it's three in the morning and the story's over and you just want to read more." ~

A fast paced, adrenaline soaked novel. . . . Lizzie, or Crazy Lizzie to her friends, makes for a rather dark character. A former cutter who has occasional suicidal tendencies, she nonetheless manages to be very compelling. In fact, all the characters manage to be interesting. . . . Slater is a very talented writer and he slowly ramps up the action and suspense until you're flipping the pages almost too fast to read the words. . . . I'll definitely be waiting (impatiently) for the sequel. ~

"Slater has created a post-apocalyptic world that is inwardly and outwardly consistent by paying attention to the details. Lizzie, the anti-hero is the tough chick with a heart of gold. She survives the pandemic apocalypse that wipes out 95 percent of the world's population [and] captures the reader by being so human that you can't help being sucked into her world.... like Rowling and Suzanne Collins, writes about young people, but engages a wider audience, ... furthering understanding of what it is like to be young in this difficult world."

For 20+ years, I've worked with students who were dealt a challenging hand, who didn't have a voice, and had trouble finding themselves in the world. These kids often don't read much, partly, I think, because they rarely see people like them in fiction. So, yes, I wrote a trilogy for folks who don't read! ;-)Many young adult books are light and fun; protagonists are often white and/or male. Though this is changing, there are not enough strong females characters who effect change in the world around themselves. I created this universe in a story in 1995. In 2011, when I came up with the idea of placing Lizzie in this universe, everything clicked.

In a future that could be ours, Lizzie, a suicidal teen-age girl, barely navigates her own life. Then everything falls apart. In an apocalyptic land nearly deserted by disease, she lacks reasons to live until a shocking turn of events reveals a phone number. Her call pulls her dangerously cross-country to meet a stranger she thought was dead.

. He has a should've-been-a doctorate B.A. in Theatre/Education, Spanish and History minors and a M.A. in Educational Technology.
